Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Probing the Pre-Eruption Magmatic Record of the Youngest Toba Tuff through Titanium and Aluminum Diffusion Timescales in Quartz Crystals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Constraining how quickly the enormous magma reservoirs that feed volcanic supereruptions can mobilize from a quiescent state to a state capable of eruption is important for overall understanding of large magma systems and the volcanic hazard they may pose. To probe the timescales of magma mobilization, chemical information contained within crystals that were growing in a magma reservoir can be extracted and used to gain insight into the timing of any changes in the conditions and processes that occurred in the magma reservoir before eruption. This project will investigate potential signals of magma mobilization in the pre-eruption growth record of quartz crystals found within the enormous (2800 km3) Youngest Toba Tuff (YTT), which explosively erupted 74,000 years ago from Toba Caldera in Sumatra, Indonesia. The research will be conducted at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore under the mentorship of Dr. Fidel Costa, a noted expert in applying chemical zoning and diffusion in crystals to timescales of magmatic system processes.

Striking near-rim zonation present within YTT quartz crystals under cathodoluminescence imaging is indicative of distinct of periods of growth for these crystals, and often with a final stage under different temperature or pressure conditions. The boundary between crystal zones represents a chemical disequilibrium where, through time at magmatic temperatures, elements will diffuse in the crystal to attain equilibrium. For this project, titanium and aluminum concentrations will be measured across crystal zone boundaries to determine the magnitude of diffusional relaxation that has occurred. The yielded diffusion profiles will then be matched to numerically modeled time-dependent profiles to determine the time elapsed between zone growth and eruption. The coupling of titanium diffusional relaxation with that of aluminum in quartz is a novel approach that should yield more robust temporal constraints and interpretations than one element alone. The results will allow the researchers to determine the onset of near-eruption quartz crystallization events, and the potential relation of these events to YTT magma system mobilization and/or alternative processes, such as syn-eruptive decompression.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was intended to provide a better understanding of the timescales over which voluminous silicic magmas are mobilized from a quiescent state to eruption. It investigated potential signals of magma mobilization in the pre-eruption growth record of quartz crystals found within the enormous (2800 km3) Youngest Toba Tuff (YTT), which explosively erupted 74,000 years ago from Toba Caldera in Sumatra, Indonesia. Quartz crystals extracted from multiple YTT pumices exhibit interior zoning indicative of distinct of periods of growth, and often with a final rim stage under different magmatic conditions based on differences in the titanium (Ti) concentration in the quartz – which is temperature, pressure and composition dependent.

During this project, quartz crystals and their host pumice were well characterized using both optical and backscattered electron (BSE) imaging. Mapping and imaging of cathodoluminescence (CL) intensity, which is related to the concentration of Ti within the quartz, was done over entire crystals and at high-resolution (1 micron steps) across distinct zoning boundaries with the quartz. CL images were calibrated to Ti through in-situ electron microprobe (EPMA) analyses. From these calibrated CL images, Ti concentration profiles across key zone boundaries were extracted. At the onset of growth for a discrete quartz zone, the difference in Ti concentration at the boundary between the newly formed and pre-existing zones is expected to be an abrupt step. However, through time (at magmatic temperatures) Ti is able to diffuse through the crystal, reducing the concentration contrast between the adjacent zones. This diffusional relaxation essentially ceases when the crystal is cooled upon eruption. Thus, the magnitude of diffusional relaxation exhibited by the measured Ti profile can be used to assess the time elapsed between quartz zone growth and eruption.

The timescales obtained by diffusional relaxation modeling revealed that rim growth on YTT quartz occurred between just decades before eruption. Furthermore, the similar timing for the onset of quartz rim growth across multiple YTT samples suggests this growth recorded a marked and temporally discrete magmatic event, and may be recording the magma chamber-wide influence of magmatic recharge or remobilization. This work also revealed that, despite the similar time of growth, the Ti concentration in the quartz rims varies systematically between different YTT samples, suggesting that the agent of recharge/remobilization may have heterogeneously impacted conditions in different parts of the magma system.

This project offers important insights into the timescales by which large silicic magma systems, and their associated supereruptions, transition from storage to eruption. These insights can enhance models for Toba and other caldera-forming systems, allowing for better assessment of the hazards they pose. The project, conducted with Nanyang Technological University in Singapore, catalyzed international collaboration and knowledge exchange. To date, results have been disseminated through presentations at Nanyang Technological University, Northern Arizona University, and at major domestic and international conferences.
